4.78.text: Thanks very much, Mark and can I welcome everybody here to this launch.

8.55.text: It really is a very timely report.

10.82.text: I want to acknowledge the Traditional Custodians of the land on which we meet

14.10.text: and pay my respects to their Elders both past and present.

17.51.text: I also want to, of course, thank our special guest, Rosie Batty

20.51.text: and all those who work tirelessly in this very important field

24.67.text: to have taken time to be with us this morning.

27.59.text: A lot's happening, of course, in the area of family violence

34.23.text: It's finally an issue on political agendas,

37.22.text: a long term national plan is in place;

39.08.text: the media is fully engaged and

42.21.text: a family violence prevention advocate has been named

46.43.text: In other words, the Nation's ears have finally tuned

49.90.text: into the message that family violence exists,

53.34.text: that it is pervasive, that it knows no demographic bounds,

58.43.text: as Mark has just alluded to.

60.84.text: At the same time, however, those who live with family violence

64.27.text: and those who work in this field know that

69.30.text: the cycle of violence and coercion rolls on.

73.18.text: Our existing resources are stretched to the limit

76.37.text: with inexplicable cuts to vital support services

83.20.text: Meanwhile, far from just one of a range of matters

87.62.text: family violence is actually core court business

91.99.text: both directly and as a backdrop to other offending.

96.28.text: What's more, it will remain so

98.77.text: and victims will remain at risk

100.73.text: unless we step back and widen our gaze.

104.49.text: The report that Rosie is launching today

109.26.text: turning the spotlight on the source of the problem

112.08.text: and bringing perpetrators of family violence squarely into view.

117.92.text: In doing so, it explains that far from a phenomenon

124.19.text: family violence consists of controlling, coercive,

129.31.text: abusive or violent behaviour used by identifiable individuals.

136.27.text: Contact with the Justice system, then,

139.21.text: represents an opportunity to intervene with these individuals;

142.71.text: an opportunity that, at this point, has not always been seized.

147.12.text: From the respondent churned through the court system

150.04.text: who does not understand the basis of a protection order;

153.12.text: to the man sitting on a behaviour change waiting list

159.85.text: from the individual jailed for a family violence assault

165.40.text: to the man who cannot be located by police

168.46.text: when an arrest needs to be made and

173.29.text: Too often the detached operation of the conventional court process

177.64.text: serves to propel perpetrators away and cement isolation

183.17.text: rather than keep them within reach of effective intervention.

187.55.text: The aim of this report is instead to write those

191.19.text: who commit family violence into the analysis.

194.76.text: In doing so, it promotes the potential of the justice system

198.83.text: as an active and involved participant

201.95.text: that can interrupt the cycle of family violence

204.35.text: and make those who use it more visible

209.04.text: by bringing him back to court to account for his commitments,

212.45.text: by making sure he's known to relevant service agencies

216.66.text: by addressing related addiction, mental health or a combination of problems

221.51.text: and by identifying whatever stake he may have in becoming a safer man.

227.84.text: It also means promoting the justice system

229.73.text: as a dynamic rather than static actor;

234.29.text: one that can adapt and tailor its responses as circumstances change,

239.00.text: that can be effective as early as possible

242.03.text: with those most likely to work towards safety

244.97.text: and which can be freed up to keep those posing a higher risk

252.27.text: The report does not suggest, of course, that these are easy solutions

256.87.text: or that there is just one easy solution.

259.69.text: The cycle of family violence is so complicated

262.47.text: that we cannot assume that one policy such as

266.37.text: the glacial road towards a National IVO Register,

269.97.text: for example, will make the difference.

273.06.text: Instead, we need a range of interventions;

276.78.text: ones which a perpetrator encounters repeatedly

280.13.text: and which reinforce over and over and over again

284.91.text: that his behaviour is something that we simply will not accept.

289.87.text: That said, the report does not call for a blunt

296.32.text: A lock 'em up and throw away the key approach

301.57.text: and certainly, imprisonment is absolutely necessary in many cases.

307.30.text: If this is our only response, however,

313.07.text: to address the violence at its source

315.82.text: and ensure there are not more victims down the track.

320.25.text: What's more, it abdicates our responsibility to acknowledge

324.00.text: that family violence is not something committed by

327.26.text: an aberrant fraction who can be pushed

331.40.text: but by a wide range of individuals whose behaviour

335.11.text: and sense of entitlement we have, collectively, allowed to endure.

340.84.text: Collectively, therefore, we have to develop a much smarter response

345.94.text: drawing on what we already know while harnassing the opportunity

349.16.text: that contact with the justice system presents

352.15.text: to step in more effectively at the earliest possible stage.

356.71.text: As a result, the report recommends that jurisdictions support

360.16.text: a dedicated conference on perpetrator interventions,

363.59.text: in addition to any national crisis summit currently being proposed.

367.75.text: It also calls for jurisdictions to develop early intervention strategies

372.07.text: and to fund a more considered and well-supported sector

378.90.text: The report also recommends the use of call-outs to police

383.77.text: as opportunities, not only to apply an appropriate criminal or civil justice response,

389.21.text: but also to make referrals to a range of other services.

394.12.text: In particular, the report highlights a need

396.47.text: for perpetrators to be referred to crisis accommodation

400.36.text: so that they do not spiral into isolation

403.79.text: and instead are kept within view.

406.95.text: It also calls for perpetrators to be connected to an active men’s referral service

414.31.text: support speedier inter-agency collaboration and ongoing contact

418.63.text: with perpetrators prior to a court appearance.

422.18.text: Once a perpetrator has contact with the court,

425.04.text: the report suggests ways in which this interaction can become much more powerful,

430.59.text: harnessing the potential of a court appearance to connect perpetrators

434.51.text: to early referral and treatment including those who may have used family violence

439.38.text: but are actually charged with other offences;

442.70.text: using bail and remand as an opportunity to do the same;

447.38.text: recognising the value of appropriately trained respondent workers

451.72.text: and duty lawyers in protection order hearings;

453.86.text: using the imprimatur of a judge’s authority to increase a perpetrator’s willingness to comply with orders,

461.25.text: applying swift and reliable sanctions and bringing perpetrators back

467.08.text: for ongoing monitoring and assessment before the court.

471.17.text: The report, then, recommends ways in which the correction system can be used more effectively.

476.48.text: To monitor offenders whilst they’re in the community,

478.72.text: to intervene in rather than perpetuate the cycle of violence in custodial settings,

484.99.text: to use these settings to screen for and identify

488.29.text: family violence perpetration in the general population of offenders

492.01.text: and to explore possibilities for ongoing monitoring post-release.

498.14.text: Importantly, the report calls on jurisdictions to interrupt the transmission of family violence between generations

505.31.text: by responding more effectively to adolescents who use violence in the home

510.30.text: as well as to children at risk of the profound harm that we know that exposure to family violence can cause.

517.76.text: Overall, these recommendations are about removing the burden from victims of family violence

524.93.text: and placing that burden squarely on the system.

529.80.text: Just as urgently, therefore, the report calls for us to face up to our own accountability

535.23.text: as individuals, as jurisdictions, and as a population at large.

540.70.text: Family violence is quite simply the greatest threat to our collective wellbeing.

548.19.text: If we’re serious about tackling this threat head on therefore,

551.90.text: we need to be prepared to commit to more and targeted resources for support services,

558.60.text: first and foremost, but also for additional interventions right along the spectrum

564.33.text: which may ultimately see these services experience less demand.

568.75.text: After all, we know enough about the costs of family violence to realise that

574.06.text: simply doing more of the same is not going to stem its ongoing drain on our social and economic future.

583.45.text: What’s more, and as an example in this report highlights,

587.61.text: interventions which prevent even one family violence related homicide

597.30.text: Substantial though the challenge might be, therefore,

600.90.text: and as entrenched as patterns of violence are in many of those who use it,

604.57.text: understanding of the cause of family violence and the

607.57.text: attitudes which support it has reached a crucial stage,

611.71.text: as has the community’s motivation to do something about it.

614.75.text: As Rosie herself has emphasised, our overall focus needs to shift

620.57.text: from simply expecting a victim to keep herself safe, to leave, to report breaches, to testify;

628.28.text: to demanding the perpetrators take responsibility for their violence and an effective intervention is applied.

635.74.text: Equally, our focus needs to shift from

638.91.text: hoping that the law will address a single incident to

642.76.text: ensuring that repeated interventions might also

646.24.text: break the cycle of violence for subsequent generations.

650.58.text: As a former politician, I know they certainly spend a great deal of time

655.17.text: talking about valuing families as well as about securing our social and economic future.

662.09.text: Addressing the violence occurring within these families then, is a crucial way of doing both.

670.95.text: This report explains there are things that we can do now to mount a more

675.27.text: comprehensive and proactive response to family violence.

679.77.text: Its aim is to show that if we widen our gaze, we can make a start,

685.63.text: broadening the conversation, seizing opportunities, stepping in earlier

690.46.text: and bringing perpetrators of family violence clearly, unequivocally, into view.

697.60.text: So I certainly want to thank all those who have contributed to this report and

701.44.text: I’d now like to introduce to you Australian of the Year, Rosie Batty, to formally launch the report. (Applause)

707.71.text: Thank you for inviting me here today to launch this report.

710.95.text: I am thrilled. We need this.

714.10.text: We need this because isn’t there a saying that says

718.53.text: keep doing what you’ve always done, you keep getting what you’ve always got.

726.31.text: The momentum that has grown over the past 12 months, 18 months

730.21.text: brings us to a point where change is fundamentally possible.

740.74.text: So you see, currently, this year alone, there are two women every week

746.83.text: being killed by family violence; it's not good enough.

753.62.text: It will continue on that vein, uninterrupted, unless we make significant change.

761.60.text: Our response to family violence through our court systems and processes is

766.74.text: paramount, integral and integral to the experience the victim receives.

774.95.text: At this point, as Rod clearly said, we place all responsibility for the safety on the victim

783.65.text: and we still ask the question: why doesn’t she leave?

788.25.text: Very simply, there are many reasons.

791.11.text: Being launched into poverty and homelessness may be one;

795.73.text: breaking up a family and leaving the home that they have worked hard to build may be another;

801.65.text: but the most significant reason, and one we’re constantly reminded of,

806.56.text: is because when you do choose to leave you are at the greatest risk of being killed

816.30.text: and just recently, another death in Canberra of a lovely woman who only had given birth

822.37.text: to a baby girl or baby a week beforehand.

826.27.text: So you see it is about power and control; this is a gender issue.

831.88.text: It is a gender issue and it is about power and control

836.00.text: and I’m living testament to the worst of those cases

840.61.text: when my little boy, Luke, was killed as a final act of power and control.

846.40.text: Now, Greg was able to dominate and control the court process because

851.78.text: in the current format and the way it operates that happens all of the time.

858.94.text: When you do have an incident that you know is serious enough to take to the police,

870.20.text: you don’t know what danger you are placing yourself in by escalating the situation

881.40.text: that you’ve consta ... you have managed so far.

885.36.text: So an AVO is an option that we’re given as if it’s the final solution and it’s going to solve everything.

894.23.text: Well, for many women it just doesn’t because it is a piece of paper.

901.23.text: And do we respond to those breaches, seriously, while often they don’t.

913.20.text: So right from the very beginning a perpetrator, somehow through his sense of entitlement

920.70.text: and that the women is his possession and the children are his possession,

923.87.text: doesn’t get that firm message, right from the very beginning, that this behaviour is not tolerated,

932.47.text: there are firm consequences should you step out of line,

937.95.text: but also what’s absolutely integral is that they are linked into intervention strategies.

946.93.text: Greg had mental health issues, he was homeless, he had marijuana usage,

956.78.text: but very importantly, he was violent.

962.66.text: So if we have a look at how we intervene with someone like Greg

968.13.text: to potentially stop a disastrous outcome, the court process, the judicial response

976.74.text: can be the most effective player to link all of this together.

982.31.text: But currently, it is a random journey.

986.15.text: You may get an informed magistrate who may

989.91.text: understand family violence and its complexities,

993.34.text: they may believe the victim and may treat them with respect.

998.28.text: But there are a lot of maybes.

1001.52.text: So potentially, a journey for a victim is harrowing;

1006.04.text: you work hard to be even believed, and in most cases unless you have the physical bruises,

1012.81.text: your violence, whether it be control, financial, psychological, sexual are harder to prove

1020.77.text: and give evidence and somehow they’re not perceived as dangerous

1025.51.text: but a lot of those instances are fatalities; it is power and control,

1036.58.text: But that stepping out of and making a decision to leave the relationship puts you in enormous danger.

1046.72.text: So I’m thrilled to see a report that places the perpetrator into focus.

1055.98.text: Currently, we victim blame and somehow the perpetrator goes under the radar; they’re allowed to control and dominate the system.

1068.35.text: Well, in this kind of model they couldn’t;

1071.57.text: they would be given an opportunity to break their violent behaviour,

1076.34.text: to understand their violent behaviour and to have the symptoms on the other underlying issues treated.

1085.05.text: And currently, we are looking at cuts to our frontline services.

1090.35.text: I’ve just come from Mildura where the Aboriginal refuge there is closing;

1095.32.text: also, the only lawyer that travels into remote country areas, the funding stops.

1104.01.text: So how we can support our victims and keep them safe when frontline services are closing is concerning.

1115.52.text: But whilst we’re looking after our victims we need to be looking after

1119.87.text: and working out effective ways to deal with our perpetrators.

1124.85.text: And as this right report indicates, that is working collaboratively and not in silos

1132.55.text: and there needs a full overhaul of our judicial system.

1136.87.text: And I believe that we are ready for that and I believe there is a lot of good intent

1141.38.text: within the judicial system to step outside the square and look at how things could be improved.

1146.50.text: But we need leadership from government, from Federal Government

1150.15.text: and we’re very lucky, here, in Australia to have Daniel Andrews

1153.51.text: who clearly gets the violence issue, he understands it being the gender issue

1158.68.text: and the investment into a Royal Commission is a great investment.

1163.87.text: So thank you for coming today and I launch the report

1170.32.text: and I’m really pleased for Rob and his team, again, to have worked so smartly,

1176.54.text: not just off on a tangent but to actually invest in stakeholders

1180.48.text: who are working on the ground on the frontline services and have done so for decades

1187.27.text: because they have helped contribute, too, to this report.

1191.15.text: And quite often those types of services and those people with that expertise get overlooked.

1197.12.text: So Rob, I’m thrilled that I was part of the report, it’s very relevant to me

1202.92.text: and it’s very relevant to every victim that’s currently unsafe

1208.90.text: and going through a very, very harrowing court process. Thank you. (Applause).

1215.72.text: And thanks to Rosie’s courage and generosity, we’re all very familiar with her story.

1219.91.text: Having been asked to investigate early interventions in the justice system

1223.55.text: and having decided to focus on family violence, what struck us, in particular, about it

1228.27.text: was the way in which the justice sector kept sending Greg away,

1231.72.text: bouncing him off the system, entrenching isolation and distorted thinking;

1236.01.text: in short, leaving it until things were too late rather than stepping in early to intervene.

1241.92.text: In many ways, then, Rosie’s story crystallised the focus of this report

1246.15.text: and we are incredibly grateful for her generosity,

1249.15.text: not only in meeting with us early in its development, but of course for her presence here today.

1253.80.text: We’re also very grateful, however, for the input of so many others in the sector

1258.31.text: which I think is, perhaps, the report’s greatest value.

1261.45.text: When we first asked stakeholders to participate we were very conscious that

1265.21.text: potentially, here was yet another report into family violence,

1269.08.text: a subject that was and still is attracting a great deal of attention

1272.35.text: and demanding a great deal of professional time.

1276.18.text: A large volume of work already exists that describes the deficiencies of the legal system,

1281.61.text: all of which needed to be reviewed, of course, in order to understand the challenge.

1285.55.text: Just another research project, however, could easily end up on the shelf,

1289.44.text: something that we at the Centre for Innovative Justice are loathe to see occur. (Audience chuckling)

1293.98.text: Instead, and thankfully, we encountered incredible openness from the sector with both their time and ideas;

1300.61.text: many spending considerable hours talking about their experiences

1304.36.text: and their thoughts for the direction in which efforts should head.

1306.87.text: In particular, and though unfortunately he couldn’t be here today,

1310.44.text: Rodney Vlais from No to Violence was a source of great knowledge and possibility

1313.98.text: pointing us in a range of directions but never prescribing the end result and I really want to thank him.

1319.31.text: More broadly, we were fortunate to speak with a wide range of professionals interstate and internationally.

1325.15.text: We spoke to behaviour change practitioners, policy officers, magistrates,

1329.84.text: court staff, lawyers, academics and, of course, women’s support services

1334.08.text: and our hope is that this report highlights in some small way the amazing work

1338.77.text: that all of these people are doing and their determination to keep women and children safe.

1344.72.text: Another hope is that this report demonstrates that the same themes

1348.09.text: emerged time and time again throughout all these consultations.

1351.68.text: Just one of them was that perpetrator accountability

1354.61.text: is a complex concept and means more than just one thing.

1359.78.text: First and foremost, of course, those consulted told us

1362.61.text: that accountability means making victims of family violence safe.

1366.14.text: Beyond this, it means keeping the perpetrator firmly in view,

1370.07.text: not isolating him or propelling him from scrutiny.

1372.52.text: It means leveraging the authority of the justice system and whatever stake

1376.21.text: in conformity a man has to ensure that he complies with orders.

1380.12.text: It means measuring the right things.

1382.75.text: It means keeping not only the violence and its user visible but also the system’s response.

1387.98.text: It means every part of the system bearing responsibility

1391.35.text: and the victim setting the pace.

1393.48.text: Just as importantly, it means coming to terms with the fact that family violence

1396.58.text: is core business in the legal system and has to be treated and funded as such.

1402.54.text: A further theme was that although perpetrators of family violence often exhibit similar traits

1407.21.text: they are still individuals with whom the justice system can and must intervene.

1411.07.text: What’s more, different interventions will be more or less successful with some than with others.

1416.56.text: For that reason, while we continue to use the terms perpetrators for reasons of consistency with the National Plan,

1422.61.text: we’ve also attempted to use language that writes men back into an unapologetically gendered analysis.

1429.48.text: Language that unpacks the homogeneous descriptions which we believe

1432.78.text: have perpetuated the system’s failures for both women and men alike.

1437.44.text: A final theme to emerge from our consultations was that there was obviously no magic solution,

1442.58.text: no quirky initiative as one sage cautioned upon which we could stumble and hold triumphantly to the sky.

1448.91.text: This was never the ambition of this report.

1451.99.text: Those who have been working in this field for decades or have lived with family violence, even for a day,

1456.78.text: know that it is far too complex to be met with just one response.

1460.31.text: Instead, the more modest ambition for this report was to reflect a certain level of consensus,

1465.39.text: to highlight opportunities, to synthesise ideas and

1469.23.text: to do so in language which might enable them to be taken up down the track.

1473.38.text: Many in the field have been saying it for a long time, the National Plan says it too,

1477.95.text: we have to talk more openly about perpetrator accountability and

1481.51.text: our hope for this report is that it provides a platform for this conversation to occur. Thank you. (Applause)
